poem:
**Morning in Gaza**

The air, thick with the echo  
of whispered prayers,  
a scattered celebration  
paints the dawn  
with shadows of hope,  

gunshots ascend,  
pierce the silence  
but still fall quiet,  
a reminder—  

even whispered  
under the sun, fear  
lingers here, hangs  
like smoke above  
the waking sea.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Everyone is still afraid’: ceasefire deal brings relief to Gaza but fears remain over future On Thursday morning, there was little joy in Gaza. The news of the imminent ceasefire had spread rapidly across the devastated territory during the night, with a few gunshots fired into the sky in celebration, but as morning came the mood was of tense anticipation. “Everyone is still afraid,” said a 26-year-old woman in al-Mawasi, the squalid, overcrowded coastal strip". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
